prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Array configuration: Our targets have expected source sizes of order 1-1.5''. As we only aim to measure the total flux of each line in each object we ask for the most compact array configuration, C34-1 or C34-2, in order to keep the phase stability at its maximum.
Correlator setup: The line width of our targets are FWHM=220-330 km/s. We aim for a velocity resolution of 50.0 km/s to resolve the line profiles. As such we ask for FDM mode with 1.875GHz bandwidth and x16 frequency binning to keep the data load at a minimum. This typically results in a velocity resolution of ~15 and 10 km/s for t he Band 4 and 6, respectively. The data will be binned to lower resolution depending on the targets FWHM and signal to noise ratio.
Sensitivity: The required sensitivity has been calculated based on the observed CO10 and CO32 flux densities and using the excitation models describedin the proposal text. The expected line intensities given in the technical section are the mean between the two models.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Recent CO observations in normal main-sequence galaxies at high redshift have shown that their star formation efficiency is lower than in case of merger driven SMGs, more consistent with the star formation efficiency in local spiral galaxies. The picture that emerges from this studies is that SMGs form stars more rapidly because their gas clouds are more compressed so they churn more quickly through the available gas reservoir than the typical normal high-z disk galaxies. These differences in the physical conditions of the ISM are expected to affect the CO and CI line ratios. Indeed earlier studies of low-J CO transitions suggest that main sequence galaxies have similar ISM properties than the MW. A coherent picture of the gas excitation in these systems, however, is missing so far.
We here aim to investigate the gas excitation in three main-sequence galaxies selected from the PHIBSS survey. We propose to study the shape of the CO SED in conjunction with both lines of atomic carbon to investigate the physical conditions of their ISM. Our study aims to provide for the first time well characterized templates of the gas excitation in high redshift main-sequence galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
